Get Started

Source: vignettes/mlr3spatiotempcv.Rmd
mlr3spatiotempcv.Rmd
set.seed(42)
library("mlr3")
library("mlr3spatiotempcv")

1 Introduction

This package provides resampling methods for the [mlr3] package framework suited for spatial and temporal data. So far, only spatial resampling methods have been properly implemented.

Calling library("mlr3spatiotempcv"), makes the spatial resampling methods and example tasks available to the user.

1.0.1 Task types

mlr_reflections$task_types
#>       type          package          task        learner        prediction
#> 1: classif             mlr3   TaskClassif LearnerClassif PredictionClassif
#> 2: classif mlr3spatiotempcv TaskClassifST LearnerClassif PredictionClassif
#> 3:    regr             mlr3      TaskRegr    LearnerRegr    PredictionRegr
#> 4:    regr mlr3spatiotempcv    TaskRegrST    LearnerRegr    PredictionRegr
#>           measure
#> 1: MeasureClassif
#> 2: MeasureClassif
#> 3:    MeasureRegr
#> 4:    MeasureRegr

1.0.2 Task column roles

# note the addtional "coordinates" slot
mlr_reflections$task_col_roles
#> $regr
#> [1] "feature"     "target"      "label"       "order"       "group"      
#> [6] "weight"      "coordinates"
#> 
#> $classif
#> [1] "feature"     "target"      "label"       "order"       "group"      
#> [6] "weight"      "coordinates"

1.0.3 Resampling methods

as.data.table(mlr_resamplings)
#>                      key                                  params iters
#>  1:            bootstrap                           repeats,ratio    30
#>  2:               custom                                             0
#>  3:                   cv                                   folds    10
#>  4:              holdout                                   ratio     1
#>  5:             insample                                             1
#>  6:  repeated-spcv-block folds,repeats,rows,cols,range,selection    10
#>  7: repeated-spcv-coords                           folds,repeats    10
#>  8:    repeated-spcv-env                  folds,repeats,features    10
#>  9:          repeated_cv                           repeats,folds   100
#> 10:           spcv-block         folds,rows,cols,range,selection    10
#> 11:          spcv-buffer               theRange,spDataType,addBG     0
#> 12:          spcv-coords                                   folds    10
#> 13:             spcv-env                          folds,features    10
#> 14:          subsampling                           repeats,ratio    30

Currently, the following resampling methods are implemented:

Literature Package Reference Class Name mlr3 Sugar
Spatial Buffering blockCV Valavi 2019 ResamplingSpCVBuffer rsmp("spcv-buffer")
Spatial Blocking blockCV Valavi 2019 ResamplingSpCVBlock rsmp("spcv-block")
Spatial CV sperrorest Brenning 2012 ResamplingSpCVCoords rsmp("spcv-coords")
Environmental Blocking blockCV Valavi 2019 ResamplingSpCVEnv rsmp("spcv-env")
— — — — —
Repeated Spatial CV sperrorest Brenning 2012 RepeatedResamplingSpCVCoords rsmp("repeated-spcv-coords")

1.1 Usage

To create a spatial task, use class TaskClassifST for classification and TaskRegrST for regression tasks. Please make sure that your dataset comes with coordinates since they are needed during the construction of the class (see the next code chunk). In addition, one can specify whether the coordinates should be used as features during the modeling. By default, coordinates are not used as features and will be removed from the feature dataset after the coordinates have been added as a method to the task. For optional plotting purposes, it is recommended to also pass the PROJ string specifying the used coordinate reference system via the crs argument.

data = mlr3::as_data_backend(readRDS(system.file("extdata", "ecuador.rda",
  package = "mlr3spatiotempcv")))

ecuador = TaskClassifST$new(id = "ecuador", backend = data, target = "slides",
  positive = "TRUE", coordinate_names = c("x", "y"), coords_as_features = FALSE,
  crs = "+proj=utm +zone=17 +south +datum=WGS84 +units=m +no_defs")

The “ecuador” dataset consists of a response variable named slides (boolean; see Figure 1.1) and various predictor variables that might have an influence on the occurrence of landslides such as slope, curvature or catchment area.1 For a detailed overview of the dataset, please refer to Brenning et al. (2015) and/or Chapter 11 of Geocomputation with R (Lovelace, Nowosad, and Muenchow 2019).

Figure 1.1: Landslide initiation points (red) and non-landslide points (blue) in Southern Ecuador. Figure taken from Lovelace, Nowosad, and Muenchow (2019).

Printing a spatial task, also displays a preview of the coordinates.

ecuador
#> <TaskClassifST:ecuador> (751 x 11)
#> * Target: slides
#> * Properties: twoclass
#> * Features (10):
#>   - dbl (10): carea, cslope, dem, distdeforest, distroad,
#>     distslidespast, hcurv, log.carea, slope, vcurv
#> * Coordinates:
#>             x       y
#>   1: 712882.5 9560002
#>   2: 715232.5 9559582
#>   3: 715392.5 9560172
#>   4: 715042.5 9559312
#>   5: 715382.5 9560142
#>  ---                 
#> 747: 714472.5 9558482
#> 748: 713142.5 9560992
#> 749: 713322.5 9560562
#> 750: 715392.5 9557932
#> 751: 713802.5 9560862

After the task has been constructed, it can be used in conjunction with all available resampling methods. However, non-spatial methods should only be used to showcase the degree of overoptimistic performance estimates compared to a chosen spatiotemporal resampling method (Schratz et al. 2019).

1.1.1 Resampling

To showcase the usage with code, we will adapt the basic resampling example of the mlr3book by using the “ecuador” example task that comes with the {mlr3spatiotempcv} package. To predict landslide occurence, we will use a simple decision tree. To emphasize that common, i.e., non-spatial, cross-validation is usually over-optimistic, we will first execute a 5-repeated 5-fold cross-validation with the help of the "repeated-cv" resampling method.

learner = lrn("classif.rpart", maxdepth = 3, predict_type = "prob")
resampling_nsp = rsmp("repeated_cv", folds = 5, repeats = 5)
rr_nsp = resample(task = ecuador, learner = learner,
  resampling = resampling_nsp)

rr_nsp$aggregate(measures = msr("classif.ce"))
#> classif.ce 
#>  0.3408706

However, as emphasized before, the “ecuador” landslides dataset is a spatial dataset, i.e., that each observation comes with xy-coordinates. And points close to each other tend to be more similar than points further apart. Spatial cross-validation takes this into account by putting points close to each other either into the training or the test dataset (see Figure 1.2). For more details on (spatial) cross-validation, please refer to Brenning (2012) and Schratz et al. (2019). For a gentle introduction to spatial cross-validation, please refer to Chapter 11 of Geocomputation with R (Lovelace, Nowosad, and Muenchow 2019). Hence, let’s do the cross-validation again, this time taking into account the spatial dimension.

resampling_sp = rsmp("repeated-spcv-coords", folds = 5, repeats = 5)

rr_sp = resample(task = ecuador, learner = learner,
  resampling = resampling_sp)

rr_sp$aggregate(measures = msr("classif.ce"))
#> classif.ce 
#>  0.3974651

We see that the classical non-spatial CV performs better. However, “better” in this case actually means overoptimistic and biased (Burman, Chow, and Nolan 1994; Cliff and Ord 1970; Racine 2000; Schratz et al. 2019). Hence, it is highly recommended to not use classical CV methods with spatiotemporal data but rather choose an appropriate spatiotemporal method.

1.2 Visualization

This package follows the {mlr3} ecosystem idea of providing autoplot() methods for certain classes.

For an exhaustive overview, have a look at the reference section for the autoplot method on the pkgdown site of this package.

To showcase the usage, we will visualize both resampling methods which we created for the comparison we just did above.

1.2.1 Spatial

Multiple options exists. If no specific fold is specified, all partitions will be returned distinguished by color.

autoplot(object = resampling_sp, task = ecuador)

Figure 1.2: Example for five spatially disjoint partitions constructed with the repeated_cv resampling method.

1.2.2 Non-spatial

autoplot(object = resampling_nsp, task = ecuador)

References

Brenning, Alexander. 2012. “Spatial cross-validation and bootstrap for the assessment of prediction rules in remote sensing: The R package sperrorest.” In 2012 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium. IEEE. https://doi.org/10.1109/igarss.2012.6352393.

Brenning, A, M Schwinn, AP Ruiz-Páez, and J Muenchow. 2015. “Landslide Susceptibility Near Highways Is Increased by 1 Order of Magnitude in the Andes of Southern Ecuador, Loja Province.” Natural Hazards & Earth System Sciences 15 (1).

Burman, Prabir, Edmond Chow, and Deborah Nolan. 1994. “A Cross-Validatory Method for Dependent Data.” Biometrika 81 (2): 351–58. https://doi.org/10.1093/biomet/81.2.351.

Cliff, Andrew D., and Keith Ord. 1970. “Spatial Autocorrelation: A Review of Existing and New Measures with Applications.” Economic Geography 46 (June): 269. https://doi.org/10.2307/143144.

Lovelace, Robin, Jakub Nowosad, and Jannes Muenchow. 2019. Geocomputation with R. 1st ed. The R Series. Boca Raton; London; New York: Chapman; Hall/CRC. https://geocompr.robinlovelace.net/.

Racine, Jeff. 2000. “Consistent Cross-Validatory Model-Selection for Dependent Data: Hv-Block Cross-Validation.” Journal of Econometrics 99 (1): 39–61. https://doi.org/10.1016/s0304-4076(00)00030-0.

Schratz, Patrick, Jannes Muenchow, Eugenia Iturritxa, Jakob Richter, and Alexander Brenning. 2019. “Hyperparameter Tuning and Performance Assessment of Statistical and Machine-Learning Algorithms Using Spatial Data.” Ecological Modelling 406 (August): 109–20. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ecolmodel.2019.06.002.

  1. Please note that the “ecuador” task is also available via tsk{ecuador}.↩︎
